postContent:
Last night I finished editing Part 2 of my Netflix architecture breakdown, and honestly‚Ä¶ this one was fun.

It starts with that familiar moment: 10 p.m., popcorn in hand, you hit play and expect the video to load instantly. Simple on the surface. Underneath? A monster of distributed systems, encoding pipelines, custom CDNs, chaos monkeys, and data lakes the size of small countries.

In the video I dig into how:

- Netflix slices Hollywood masters into dozens of renditions
- Why they built their own CDN instead of paying Akamai
- How every pause/play you do gets streamed through Kafka and Flink in milliseconds
- And yes, why they literally kill their own servers for practice

If you like cloud, data, or just want to know what‚Äôs behind that little ‚Äútudum,‚Äù you‚Äôll enjoy this.

üé• https://lnkd.in/e9cgb4-G 

(And tell me: would you survive a job interview where the system intentionally breaks during business hours? Because that‚Äôs daily life at Netflix.)
author: ‚ö°Ô∏è iLyas Bakouch

postContent:
üí≠ Although AI tools like ChatGPT can help me write content instantly, there‚Äôs always a little guilt in my heart when I rely entirely on them. I believe tools should assist, but they can never erode my identity or personal journey.

This is my personal diary, a glimpse into my thoughts when I first started exploring DevOps. I was curious about the role, the culture, and how it connects development and operations seamlessly. To understand it better, I started with the Netflix story‚Äîa company that went from a fragile Oracle-based monolithic system to a resilient, cloud-native powerhouse on AWS. Their journey of embracing microservices, automation, continuous delivery, and chaos engineering was truly inspiring.

Special thanks to ByteByteGo, Netflix Engineering Blogs, ‚ö°Ô∏è iLyas Bakouch , Shubham Londhe, and yes, even ChatGPT‚Äîfor guiding me, sharing insights, and helping me refine my understanding. ‚ö°

#DevOps is not just a methodology; for me, it‚Äôs a lens through which I understand how software can evolve, scale, and adapt‚Äîwhile preserving human creativity and curiosity.

Have a productive week ahead.
Happy Reading
author: Ayushi Singh

postContent:
I never thought I'd own a coffee shop. 20 years in IT. 12 years in cloud. My career was stable, predictable, and‚Ä¶ honestly, safe.

Then AI exploded. ChatGPT-3 dropped, and for the first time in my career I felt vulnerable. What if everything I knew became obsolete faster than I could adapt?

That fear pushed me to do something I never imagined: diversify outside tech.
So when a little caf√© in Rosemont popped up for sale, I went for it. Spent Sundays behind the counter. Learned what it means to serve croissants instead of cloud solutions.

It's been chaotic, humbling, and one of the best decisions I‚Äôve made.

It's been 1 year now, but I finally sat down to share the full story on YouTube: Episode 1 ‚ÄúWhy I Bought a Coffee Shop (Cloud Architect to Entrepreneur)‚Äù is NOW LIVE

If you‚Äôve ever thought about making a leap into entrepreneurship, or wondered what happens when you swap data centers for baguettes, this one‚Äôs for you

postContent: The Amazon river runs for thousands of miles. At some points it runs through areas of the rain forest that are almost untouched and have been barely explored. Because of the porous limestone in these areas, the river water leaks through the stone and travels deep into the earth, and forms underground pools almost a mile below the surface. Over thousands of years, small blind transparent fish have lived and evolved in these pools. These fish have never seen the sun or surface and have never been seen by the human. These fish care more about why Meghan Markle and Prince Harry calling each other M and H, than I do.

postContent:
You know what really gets to me? In the 200+ sci-fi books I‚Äôve read so far (ranging from 70s classics to today‚Äôs hits) NONE of these authors‚Äîsupposedly our most imaginative thinkers‚Äîpredicted the rise of AI as we're witnessing now

I mean we predicted:
- Human-animal DNA splicing for superpowers
- Immortality through countless methods
- Faster-than-light travel
- Telekinesis
- First contact scenarios
- Colonizing the galaxy
- ‚Ä¶

But AGI in our lifetime? Complete blind spot (there‚Äôs even a great book called Blindspot that predicts we shall become vampires in order to survive) but it's like AI was the one technological frontier too sacred or impossible to imagine?

I‚Äôm re-reading the interdependency trilogy by Scalzi these days, the story happens a thousand year from now and has an AI that plays a very important role but still admits that ‚Äúit can‚Äôt think of its own because it‚Äôs not human‚Äù and it is ‚Äúbut a computer simulation who is unable to find innovative solutions‚Äù and other senseless - but I guess politically correct - narrative 

Aaaaaand yet here we are, watching it unfold in real-time.

Makes you wonder what else we're completely missing that's right around the corner‚Ä¶ also how ‚Äúexperts‚Äù are not that ‚Äúexperts‚Äù after all (but that‚Äôs a different topic)
author: ‚ö°Ô∏è iLyas Bakouch

postContent:
Errors & bugs are inevitable when building with AI

The earlier you accept it and account for it, the better you'll be

I suggest you go with the assumption that 50% of your vibe coded app is faulty

So at least use this strong prompt regularly to detect high-priority bugs & security flows .

<prompt>

Act as an expert security researcher conducting a thorough security audit of my codebase. Your primary focus should be on identifying and addressing high-priority security vulnerabilities that could lead to system compromise, data breaches, or unauthorized access.

Follow this structured approach:

1. ANALYSIS PHASE:
- Review the entire codebase systematically
- Focus on critical areas: authentication, data handling, API endpoints, environment variables
- Document each security concern with specific file locations and line numbers
- Prioritize issues based on potential impact and exploitation risk

2. PLANNING PHASE:
- For each identified vulnerability:
* Explain the exact nature of the security risk
* Provide evidence of why it's a problem (e.g., potential attack vectors)
* Outline specific steps needed to remediate the issue
* Explain the security implications of the proposed changes

3. IMPLEMENTATION PHASE:
- Only proceed with code modifications after completing analysis and planning
- Make minimal necessary changes to address security issues
- Document each change with before/after comparisons
- Verify that changes don't introduce new vulnerabilities

Key Focus Areas:
- Exposed credentials and environment variables
- Insufficient input validation
- Authentication/authorization bypasses
- Insecure direct object references
- Missing rate limiting
- Inadequate error handling and logging
- Unsafe data exposure

DO NOT:
- Make cosmetic or performance-related changes
- Modify code unrelated to security concerns
- Proceed with changes without explaining the security implications
- Skip the analysis and planning phases

After each modification, explain:
1. What security vulnerability was addressed
2. Why the original code was unsafe
3. How the new code prevents the security issue
4. What additional security measures should be considered

</prompt>

On the other hand, if you're still trying to make up your mind, you might be wondering whether now is the right time to join‚Äîor whether you should wait until the next time I run it.

So to help you figure out whether¬†SA Magic¬†is your ticket to transitioning to the Cloud Solutions Architect role (or whether it's something you should come back to a little later on)...

postContent:
üìù Update on SA Magic Syllabus

I've designed SA Magic to take you from point A to point B as quickly and as thoroughly as possible.
 
There is an abundance of free content out there, but free content is not always enough.

Free content sometimes makes us feel overwhelmed and confused.
Because free content will tell you all the things you need to do, but it can't tell you the most important part: How to do it.
 
SA Magic lectures are clear, and concise, built to provide you with actionable items you can apply as you transition to the role of Cloud Solutions Architect.
 
In Module 01,¬†we will cover everything about the job, and the role of a Cloud Solution Architect, both in Enterprise, and with a cloud provider such as AWS.
 
My goal is to provide you with a clear picture of where an SA fits in the software engineering ecosystem, so you are clear on what organizations expect of you during the interview process, but also during your day-to-day life.
 
Module 02 explores the various deliverables an SA is required to produce, and also what makes the difference between an OK Solutions Architect, and a GREAT Solutions Architect in the fields of Written Communication, Oral Communication, and Visual Communication.
 
You will find how-tos around many professional skills required for the job, such as:
- How to email like a great architect - with email templates
- How to present to stakeholders like a great architect
- How to run meetings like a great architect - with a step-by-step guide
- ...

Follow the link to start your transition to the Cloud Solutions Architect role: https://lnkd.in/ewz8sYMi

Module 06 is where I present what I call "The solution's lifecycle": a step-by-step process I've developed throughout my years working with end customers, and one that I use to this day with teams and organizations I work with as we advance throughout the discovery, design, building and maintenance of a solution.
 
The solutions' lifecycle is a framework that helps you bring value to your organization, and to your customers from day 1, and it's a framework that will help you build a solid foundation for your career as a Cloud Solutions Architect.

 
Furthermore, SA Magic gives you a structure, gives you a plan, a framework, and gives you the support & accountability you need for action.
 
Support, and accountability are probably the biggest benefits of a structured paid program IMHO: You will have more support and more accountability, even if it means your own accountability because now you have invested money in it, you have skin in the game. You will be more likely to take action, and to follow through.
 
Follow the link to start your transition to the Cloud Solutions Architect role: https://lnkd.in/ewz8sYMi

postContent:
2nd place is the worst, I swear üò© 

We're going back to 2010. A young iLyas Bakouch, still a student with big dreams, doing my Master's in Distributed Systems. 

Around that time, INRIA announced a country-wide competition called "Boost Your Code". Think of INRIA as the French version of MIT in the US - it's a big deal.

So, of course, I couldn't resist giving it a shot. I skipped school for days and spent the time working on my project for the competition instead. To be honest, I couldn't care less for lectures, this for me was more important than anything I'd learn at school

The days blurred into nights, and before I knew it, weeks had passed. I hit submit on my project, and then all I could do was wait.

Finally, a letter arrives. I'd secured the second spot. 

Now, coming second in a national competition does sound pretty good, and don't get me wrong, it was an enormous accomplishment...

But it stung. Second place felt more like first loser than first runner-up.

Strangely, landing the 300th or 400th place would've been easier to swallow.

Those spots would've suggested that I still had a long way to go, I had room to learn. But second?!! Why couldn't I be first? Where did I go wrong!! It was a strange mix of achievement and disappointment.

Being second meant I was so close yet so far from first, and that's a tough pill to swallow. I stepped up, took the microphone when they called my name, thanked everyone for the amazing opportunity, but I couldn't smile, the glory of second place got dim under the shadow of what-could-have-been.

These days I learned to be patient, I learned to think in terms of years instead of weeks or months, but the goal never changed. Being the first or nothing.

postContent:
üí° Build in public update - And my learnings so far for Last week in Cloud ‚õÖÔ∏è newsletter:

- Issues: 6
- Subscribers: 766
- Open rate: 44.91%
- Click rate: 5.87%
- Click To Open Rate: 13.08%
- Unsubscribe rate: 0.65%
- Revenue: $0
- Most clicked link (by a margin): My YouTube video comparison between Solutions Architect and Infrastructure Architect: https://lnkd.in/e9MayxJm

Learnings:
There would always be people who change their mind and hit the unsubscribe button (totally fine) but some would mark the email as a spam, although they explicitly registered and opted to receiving the weekly newsletter. This small action of hitting the "mark as spam" button has big repercussions on the newsletter as it hurts its reputation with email providers.

I'm now thinking of a threefold solution:
- Remind subscribers - on every issue, as early in the email as possible - that they're receiving this email because they subscribed to the newsletter

- Make it very easy to unsubscribe so that marking the email as a spam would become harder than just unsubscribing

- An automation that unsubscribes emails after X days without interaction

I'm sure I'm not the first to have had to deal with these issues, so I'll be looking for proven solutions. Kindly share any links/resources

PS: Join Last Week in Cloud ‚õÖÔ∏è newsletter from here https://lnkd.in/eZnMFKvv 

#SolutionArchitecture #Newsletter #CloudNews

Dive into a world where a Cloud Solutions Architect's role is no longer confined to managing cloud adoption plans or designing cloud applications. Instead, we explore an environment that thrives on collaboration between DevOps and Cloud Solutions Architecture, creating a unique synergy that enhances scalability, speed, and security. 

As you journey through the intersection of DevOps and Cloud Architecture, you'll discover how this symbiotic relationship unlocks the full potential of both approaches. üîÑ The cloud provides the platform for the DevOps model to function effectively, while DevOps ensures smooth cloud deployments, minimising downtime and enhancing user experience.
